question_details.query: Which interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) increased the abundance of brown crabs on and around structures in one study, while another study reported mixed effects on invertebrate abundances when holes were implemented alongside pits, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material [3434].
- Constructing artificial reefs with specific materials/designs increased some invertebrates: breakwaters made of bags of oyster shells recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels than “ReefBall” breakwaters, and in one case “sea-friendly” concrete pyramid reefs had higher overall abundance than plinth‑pole structures after three years [2259].
- Other surface‑complexity interventions showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on species, site or surface orientation: creating grooves (1–50 mm) [3448], pits (1–50 mm) [3455], combined grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1–50 mm) [3452], textured surfaces (≤1 mm) [3449], and adding short (1–50 mm) [3450] or long (>50 mm) [3451] flexible habitats.
